Here are the relevant news articles:

**Could Zohran Mamdani Win New York’s 2025 Mayoral Election?**
Zohran Mamdani, a 33‑year‑old member of the New York State Assembly, has become the unexpected front‑runner for the 2025 New York City mayoral race.  According to a poll by AARP New York‑Gotham Polling & Analytics, he leads with 41.8 % voter intent, outpacing former governor Andrew Cuomo and incumbent mayor Eric Adams.  Mamdani’s platform is a democratic‑socialist agenda that includes a rent‑freeze and a higher minimum wage, and he has received endorsements from Bernie Sanders, Alexandria Ocasio‑Cortez and the Working Families Party.  Critics argue that his fiscal proposals could trigger capital flight and reduce investment.  Fund‑raising figures show Cuomo raised more than $1.5 million from Long Island, while Adams has exceeded $1 million; Mamdani’s campaign has raised less, relying mainly on progressive voters and marginalized communities.  The article portrays Mamdani as a potential disruptor of the traditional establishment, but acknowledges the financial and political hurdles he faces.
Original language: es
Publish date: September 17, 2025 12:11 AM
Source:[Clarin](https://www.clarin.com/estados-unidos/podria-zohran-mamdani-ganar-elecciones-new-york_0_km3e5d1DuM.html)

**Socialist NYC Mayoral Nominee Refuses to Endorse Hochul, Despite Her Support**
Socialist Democrat Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic nominee for New York City mayor, has declined to endorse Gov. Kathy Hochul's 2026 re‑election campaign, even after Hochul publicly supported him in a New York Times op‑ed. Mamdani told reporters his focus is 'on November,' and said, 'I'm excited to have the governor's support,' without committing to reciprocation. Hochul's endorsement came while other top Democrats, such as Hakeem Jeffries and Chuck Schumer, have withheld public backing. Mamdani’s platform includes raising the minimum wage to $30, opening state‑run grocery stores, and taxing what he calls 'richer and whiter' neighborhoods, prompting business owners to voice concerns and some to consider leaving the city. He has also been criticized for not condemning anti‑police slogans like 'globalize the intifada' and the phrase 'From the river to the sea'; he now says he 'discourages' the use of the latter only after pressure from Jewish leaders. The article argues that Hochul’s endorsement signals a shift in the Democratic Party toward the far left and warns that her gamble could cost her political capital. The editor’s note invites readers to support Townhall’s conservative reporting.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 17, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[Townhall](https://townhall.com/tipsheet/saraharnold/2025/09/16/socialist-nyc-mayoral-nominee-refuses-to-endorse-hochul-despite-her-support-n2663436)

**New York Democratic governor endorses Zohran Mamdani after he kowtows to billionaires**
On Sunday, after a 12‑week delay, New York Governor Kathy Hochul endorsed Zohran Mamdani, the winner of the June Democratic mayoral primary, as reported by the World Socialist on September 16 2025. The endorsement followed a meeting between Mamdani and billionaire former mayor Michael Bloomberg, who did not endorse him but met with him, according to the article. Hochul’s endorsement broke a pattern of stone‑walling by senior Democrats, including Senators Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Mamdani is the frontrunner in a four‑way November 4 election that also includes former Governor Andrew Cuomo (running as an independent), incumbent Mayor Eric Adams (also independent) and Republican Curtis Sliwa. House members Pat Ryan, Gerry Nadler, Senator Chris Van Hollen and Representative Jamie Raskin have publicly endorsed Mamdani. Trump reacted to the endorsement with a threat, saying, 'This is a rather shocking development, and a very bad one for New York City. How can such a thing happen? Washington will be watching this situation very closely. No reason to be sending good money after bad!' The article also notes that Hochul’s op‑ed in the New York Times emphasized police resources, quoting her as saying, 'I urged him to ensure that there is strong leadership at the helm of the N.Y.P.D. -- and he agreed.' It further describes Hochul as a right‑wing figure who has opposed driver’s licenses for immigrant workers and deployed National Guard troops in subways. The piece portrays Bloomberg’s meeting as cordial but not an endorsement, and claims that Mamdani has agreed to abandon certain rhetoric and will accept police presence, while warning that Trump may deploy the National Guard in New York City. The article is heavily political and sensational in tone.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 16, 2025 03:13 AM
Source:[World Socialist](https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2025/09/16/nkjc-s16.html)

**Mamdani declines to immediately back NY Gov. Kathy Hochul's reelection after she offers him coveted endorsement**
Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, a democratic socialist, declined to endorse Gov. Kathy Hochul for a second term after she endorsed him for mayor. He said, 'My focus is on November,' and added, 'And I'm excited to have the governor's support in that fight for November as we make it clear that we can put the days of City Hall and Albany being at war in the past.' Hochul, a moderate Democrat, had endorsed him after weeks of hesitation, a move that has pressured other New York Democrats to support him. Mamdani's decision comes as Hochul faces potential challenges from Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado in the 2026 Democratic primary and from Republican Elise Stefanik in the general election. In a New York Times op‑ed, Hochul wrote, 'I do not see eye to eye on everything' with him but will stand together against those who attempt to tear us apart.

**The Democratic Party is in fits over Mamdani's bid for NYC mayor. Republicans are loving it**
Democratic Senator Chris Van Hollen criticized his party’s leadership for not endorsing Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic nominee for New York City mayor, calling the stance 'spineless' and urging Democrats to support him. Mamdani, a 33‑year‑old self‑described democratic socialist, has drawn support from progressives but has been distanced by moderate Democrats and party leaders. Republican figures, including former President Donald Trump, have seized on the split, labeling Mamdani a communist and threatening to withhold federal funds. Democratic leaders such as House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer have declined to endorse him, citing strategic considerations. Governor Kathy Hochul endorsed Mamdani, while other New York representatives have split, with Rep. Tom Suozzi refusing endorsement and Rep. Pat Ryan supporting him. The divide echoes the earlier rise of Senator Bernie Sanders, who has defended Mamdani. National progressive groups and figures like Joseph Geevarghese and Abdul El‑Sayed have expressed frustration at the establishment’s silence. Republicans in New Jersey and Virginia have linked Mamdani to the Democratic brand in their campaigns. The controversy is seen as a test of the Democratic Party’s unity heading into the 2026 midterm elections.

**Mamdani Apologizes for Anti‑Police Remarks, Faces Mixed Reactions**
On September 15, 2025, New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani publicly apologized for earlier remarks that criticized the NYPD as "racist, anti‑gay, and a major threat to public safety," according to a report by Epoch Times journalist Wang Liefei. Mamdani, a Democratic socialist, had long advocated for police budget cuts since the 2020 death of George Floyd. The shift in his stance followed the July 28, 2025 shooting in Midtown Manhattan, where gunman Shane Tamura fired nearly 50 rounds, killing five people, including a fallen officer— the deadliest mass shooting in the city in 25 years. The incident prompted mixed reactions: some politicians praised his acknowledgment of the limits of police‑budget cuts, while former Governor Gavin Newsom criticized the change as inconsistent. Police union leader Patrick Hendry demanded more than a verbal apology, calling for concrete actions to improve officer pay and working conditions. Mamdani now faces dual pressure—to appease the 30,000‑plus NYPD workforce and to retain progressive voters’ trust. Meanwhile, Governor Hoch expressed support, saying, 'He should apologize. I think this is an appropriate response. He acknowledges the mistake and works to earn officers’ respect, and I appreciate that.' Hoch also formally endorsed Mamdani for mayor, marking a significant alliance between the party’s moderate and progressive wings. The outcome of Mamdani’s attempt to resolve the controversy will be a key test of his campaign’s viability.

**Mamdani-like Democratic Socialist Omar Fateh loses key endorsement in...**
Minneapolis mayoral candidate Omar Fateh, a Democratic Socialist, lost the endorsement of the Minnesota Democratic‑Farmer‑Labor Party (DFL) after the party’s Constitution, Bylaws & Rules Committee found substantial failures in the July 19th voting process at the Minneapolis Convention. DFL Party Chairman Richard Carlbom said, 'After a thoughtful and transparent review of the challenges, the Constitution, Bylaws & Rules Committee found substantial failures in the Minneapolis Convention's voting process on July 19th, including an acknowledgement that a mayoral candidate was errantly eliminated from contention.' **Mamdani-like Democratic Socialist Omar Fateh loses key endorsement in Minneapolis mayoral race**
Omar Fateh, a 35‑year‑old Somali American state senator and Democratic Socialist, lost the DFL endorsement for the Minneapolis mayoral race after a review of the party’s contested convention voting process found substantial flaws. The review, conducted by the Constitution, Bylaws & Rules Committee, identified a 176‑vote undercount on the first ballot and the improper removal of candidate DeWayne Davis. DFL Party Chairman Richard Carlbom said the committee vacated the endorsement, citing failures in the electronic voting system and credentialing process. Fateh had secured more than 60 % of delegate votes at the convention. In a campaign video, Fateh said, 'Twenty‑eight party insiders voted to take away our endorsement behind closed doors,' and added that the group was made up of 'non‑Minneapolis residents, Mayor Frey’s supporters and even donors.' He criticized the process as an 'insider game' and vowed to win. Mayor Jacob Frey, who was elected in 2017 and re‑elected in 2021, praised the party for correcting the 'inaccurate and obviously flawed process' and said he would debate Fateh openly. Fateh’s platform—rent stabilization, affordable housing and higher taxes on the wealthy—mirrors that of New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani, whom he followed after Mamdani’s upset victory. Fateh will face Frey in the November election.

summary:
Across a diverse set of expert perspectives covering political strategy, electoral analysis, political science, sociology, and minority representation, forecasts for Omar Fateh’s chances in the 2025 Minneapolis mayoral election range from modest underdog status to slight favorite, reflecting a high degree of uncertainty and volatility. 

A recurring base rate is that incumbents in Minneapolis have won 60% of mayoral elections since 2001. However, unique factors in 2025—most notably Fateh’s initial DFL endorsement (later rescinded), a strong wave of progressive/DSA energy nationally (exemplified by Mamdani’s NYC win), Frey's deeply negative favorability (-21%), and a less divided left/progressive field—substantially increase Fateh’s competitiveness relative to the typical challenger. Most analysts note the vacating of the DFL endorsement as a real setback for Fateh, diminishing institutional backing and potentially demobilizing some of his base, but conversely, his position as the insider-outsider progressive uniting much of the left remains unique. Ranked-choice voting is seen as providing a slight advantage to Fateh if progressives stay unified, but risks persist if moderate or process-conscious voters coalesce around Frey due to party chaos. Demographic and identity dynamics (Fateh’s status as a Somali-American Muslim and community mobilization potential) are seen as both opportunities and points of risk, with possible backlash or anti-progressive sentiment among older and moderate voters.

Final probabilities offered by forecasters cluster in a relatively narrow band, mostly between 38% and 63% for a Fateh victory. A few analysts see Fateh as a slight favorite (56–63%), citing progressive momentum and anti-Frey sentiment outweighing organizational confusion. Others (38–44%) view him as a slight to moderate underdog, citing structural and procedural headwinds, historical incumbency, and uncertainty about turnout and coalition durability. In the middle, several forecasts (40–57%) reflect a tossup dynamic but give a marginal edge to anti-incumbent sentiment and national progressive energy. All agree the race is highly competitive, with turnout, effective coalition consolidation, and last-minute campaign dynamics likely to be decisive.

In summary, experts expect a close, high-variance contest, with Fateh’s chances materially improved over historic base rates, but neither candidate a prohibitive favorite. The outcome will likely hinge on turnout shifts, coalition unity, and the ability of each side to overcome or exploit the lingering effects of the DFL endorsement controversy.
